results.title: Why Brandon Perea’s ‘Nope’ Audition Made Jordan Peele Cry
results.abstract: The actor’s unexpected take on Angel, the Fry’s worker, so won over the director that he decided during their meeting to rewrite the script.

multimedia.caption: Perea said the dialogue he was handed for his “Nope” audition depicted Angel as a happy, up worker. “I was like, ‘Hmm, you don’t see that when you go into an electronics store. The employees do not want to be there.’”
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Perea said the dialogue he was handed for his “Nope” audition depicted Angel as a happy, up worker. “I was like, ‘Hmm, you don’t see that when you go into an electronics store. The employees do not want to be there.’”
multimedia.copyright: Victor Llorente for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Perea said the dialogue he was handed for his “Nope” audition depicted Angel as a happy, up worker. “I was like, ‘Hmm, you don’t see that when you go into an electronics store. The employees do not want to be there.’”

results.title: B.J. Novak Went to Texas Looking for ‘Vengeance’ and Found America
results.abstract: The first film from a former star of “The Office” is a dark comedy about life in a nation that’s not as divided as we might think.

multimedia.caption: “I thought that these huge dudes with beards and pickup trucks would be very suspicious of a Hollywood blue-state guy, and I found the exact opposite,” B.J. Novak said of his research trips to Texas.
multimedia.copyright: Erik Tanner for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “I thought that these huge dudes with beards and pickup trucks would be very suspicious of a Hollywood blue-state guy, and I found the exact opposite,” B.J. Novak said of his research trips to Texas.

results.title: The Japanese Author Behind ‘Bullet Train’ Is OK That the Film Isn’t So Japanese
results.abstract: Kotaro Isaka dreamed that his novel would get the big-screen treatment. Now it’s an action thriller starring Brad Pitt. Does the lack of major Asian stars matter?

multimedia.caption: With the release of the action thriller “Bullet Train,” based on his novel, the work of Kotaro Isaka may become better known in the West.
multimedia.copyright: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Vengeance’ Review: A Dish Best Served With Frito Pie
results.abstract: In this comedic culture-war thriller, B.J. Novak, who wrote and directed, plays an aspiring podcaster chasing a true-crime story in West Texas.

results.title: Rediscovering Australia’s Generation of Defiant Female Directors
results.abstract: Gillian Armstrong, Jane Campion, Essie Coffey and others had waited years to tell their stories, as a Museum of the Moving Image series shows.

results.title: Paul Sorvino: A Voluble Man Who Excelled as a Brick of a Mobster
results.abstract: The actor may be best known for “Goodfellas,” but he almost bailed on it because the character of the underboss Paulie Cicero was so difficult to pin down.

multimedia.caption: Paul Sorvino as the mob underboss who gave orders with just a nod of his head in “Goodfellas.”

results.title: An Avant-Garde Film That Went for Laughs Instead of Scandal
results.abstract: Nothing controversial: Adolfas Mekas’s “Hallelujah the Hills,” from 1963, is romantic slapstick, with two guys competing for the same young woman.

results.title: Bernard Cribbins, British Actor Known for ‘Doctor Who,’ Is Dead at 93

results.title: Paul Sorvino, Master of the Mild-Mannered Mobster, Dies at 83
results.abstract: A would-be singing star, he found success in Hollywood playing a variety of roles, but they were often quiet, dangerous men, like Paulie Cicero in “Goodfellas.”

multimedia.caption: Paul Sorvino in 1976. He sang and performed onstage before finding his stride in movies and television.

results.title: Bob Rafelson, Director of ‘Five Easy Pieces,’ Dies at 89
results.abstract: A central figure in the New Hollywood movement, he was also the co-creator of the TV pop group the Monkees and featured it in a movie, “Head.”

multimedia.caption: The director Bob Rafelson in 1987. A skilled navigator of the rapidly shifting pop-culture landscape of the 1960s, he was a producer of “Easy Rider.”
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Doris Thomas/Fairfax Media via Getty Images

results.title: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
results.abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.

multimedia.caption: The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.
The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.
